context: Susie works as a doctor in a hospital. In her spare time, she gives classes at the local college.
target: Susie is a doctor X she is a teacher.

context: Paul needs to do some ironing, but he finds it boring, so he turns on the TV to watch his favourite program while he irons.
target: Paul is watching TV X he is ironing his shirts.

context: Susie works as a doctor. She mainly treats patients who cannot pay for their treatment, so Susie earns much less money than other doctors.
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.

context: You live in a place where doctors are wealthy. Susie works as a doctor. She mainly treats patients who cannot pay for their treatment, so Susie earns much less money than other doctors do. You tell your friend about Susie:
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.

context: Jen bought a big ice cream cone. Instead of eating it herself though, she gave it to a sad-looking stranger who was sitting by himself on a bench.
target: Jen bought ice cream X she bought it for a stranger.

context: Paul told his grandmother that he works in a hospital and now his grandma tells everyone that Paul is a doctor. But this is not true, Paul actually works at the reception!
target: Paul is not a doctor X he is a receptionist.

context: Jen was planning to buy herself some ice cream after work, but the store was all out of ice cream! So Jen decided to buy some chocolate instead.
target: Jen didn’t buy ice cream X she bought chocolate.

context: On a multiple choice maths test, it asks “5x5” and lists two options (A) 24 and (B) 25. The teacher says the student:
target: The answer to the question is A X the answer to the question is B.

context: You and your friend are playing a game guessing the jobs of Paul and John. She can’t think of the answer, and she asks you for a hint. You know that Paul is a doctor, and that John used to be a doctor but is not anymore. So you say:
target: Paul is a doctor X John is a doctor.

context: You have lost your phone. You remember it at your work office desk before cycling home.
target: I left my phone at work X dropped it on my way home.

context: John used to be a doctor and a professional writer, but he recently quit (only) one of the professions. You don’t know which profession he quit.
target: John is a doctor X he is a writer now.

context: Your friend asks you what John’s job is. As far as you know, John might be a doctor. You’re not sure, though. It’s also possible that he’s a writer.
target: John is a doctor X he is a writer

context: John used to be a doctor and a professional writer, but he might have quit one of the professions. You’re not sure though, he might be a doctor now, he might be a writer, he might also be both. Your friend asks you what John does for a living, you say:
target: John is a doctor X he is a writer (maybe both).

context: Your friend asks you what John’s job is. You’re not sure: he might be a doctor, he might be a writer, he might also be both. You say:

context: You have lost your phone. You tell a friend that you remember having it last either on the bus coming home from work, or at your work office desk. Your friend asks you:

context: You come home from work and realise that you have lost your phone. You tell your friend, whom you called from your office right before you left work. Your friend asks you:

context: You really want a particular brand of sauce for something you plan on cooking later, but you’re not sure which supermarket would sell it. You ask your housemate:
target: Would Shop A sell this brand X would Shop B sell this brand?

context: Paul works in a hospital. He is not a doctor and he is not a nurse. He works at the reception.
target: Paul is a doctor X he is a nurse.

target: Mike didn’t buy ice cream nor did he give it to his sister.

target: Susie isn’t a doctor or a runner. (= It’s not the case that Susie is a doctor or that Susie is a runner.)

context: Paul’s mother told him to iron his shirts, but Paul is not doing that. Instead, he is watching TV. Paul’s sister knows that Paul is watching TV, and when their mother asks her what Paul is doing, she is in a difficult situation. She doesn’t want to lie but she also doesn’t want to snitch on Paul, so she says that he is doing one of those two things:
target: Paul is watching TV X he is ironing his shirts.

context: Paul needs to iron his shirts, but he would much rather watch his favourite TV programme. Paul’s sister knows that he is definitely doing one of these things, but she doesn’t know which of the two things Paul decided to do. So when her mother asks her what Paul is doing, Paul’s sister says:
target: Paul is watching TV X he is ironing his shirts.

context: Paul needs to iron his shirts, but he would much rather watch his favourite TV programme. Paul’s sister knows that he is doing one of these things, but he might also be doing both, as Paul is very good at multitasking. So when her mother asks her what Paul is doing, Paul’s sister says:
target: Paul is watching TV X he is ironing his shirts.

context: Paul needs to iron his shirts, but he would much rather watch his favourite TV programme. Paul’s mother asks his sister which of these things Paul is doing, but the sister knows that Paul is not ironing and he is not watching TV. She actually saw Paul sleeping on the sofa! Paul’s sister says:
target: Paul is watching TV X he is ironing his shirts.

context: You live in a place where doctors as well as people who don’t have much money get discounts on public trains. Your friend asks you why Susie paid so little for her last train ride. You know that Susie is not a doctor and that Susie is very poor, but she doesn’t want people to know that. Since you don’t want to embarrass Susie and you also don’t want to lie, you mention two possible reasons for Susie’s discount:
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.

context: You live in a place where doctors get paid very well and are highly appreciated, and where poor people get a lot of support. For example, doctors as well as people who don’t have much money get discounts on public trains. Your friend asks you why Susie paid so little on her last train ride. You don’t know anything about Susie, but you can think of two possible reasons:
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.

context: You live in a place where some doctors earn very little money and accumulate a lot of debt to finish their studies. So doctors sometimes struggle financially, but they are highly appreciated. Therefore, all doctors get discounts on public trains no matter how much money they have. Besides, all poor people get discounts on trains as well. Your friend asks you why Susie paid so little on her last train ride. You don’t know much about Susie, but you can imagine that Susie might be a doctor, she might be poor, she might also be both. You say to your friend:
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.

context: You live in a place where all doctors get paid very well and are highly appreciated, and where poor people get a lot of support. In fact, doctors as well as people who don’t have much money get discounts on public trains. Your friend asks whether Susie will get a discount. You know that Susie doesn’t meet either condition for a discount, so you say:
target: Susie is a doctor X she is poor.
